ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .

The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.

Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: What a wonderfully refreshing and invaluable course. I only wish it were a full year instead of semester. In a program centered around our responsibility towards the environment and environmental stewardship, how often does one actually sit back and contemplate his or her relationship to the environment? Almost never. And at a program that leverages its presence within the greater institution of Yale, how often does one get the opportunity to explore the rich resources that the university as a whole offers? Almost never, unless a student proactively chooses to take courses outside of FES.This course was an amazing opportunity to reflect on one's own relationship with his or her surroundings, the environment, and realize the constructs within which s/he exists while visiting the Peabody, Yale Art Gallery, British Art Center, Rare Maps Collection at Sterling Library, and Rare Books Collection at Beinecke. These are all resources that I have heard numerous students have on their "bucket lists" as commencement approaches (and sadly are not always able to check-off), so it was wonderful that they were integrated into the framework of the course.

To be at Yale and not to learn anything about Yale is a shame. You fail as a environmental manager if you do not know your surroundings well. I feel this is a must take course to understand why you are here and learn more in the process.
Dr. Draghi is an excellent lecturer and genuinely interested in students.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trips, the diversity of student backgrounds in the class, the professor's knowledge of the material.

The museum visits were amazing. I would never have gone out to take advantage of the museum resources that Yale has to offer without taking this class. It is also great to have a course that is very different from the traditional read-memorize-regurgitate-write model that made you think without the traditional stress.
field trips and in class discussions
See response to Q13.
The filed trips and the wealth of knowledge the professor had to share.

I felt that the best aspects of the course was the lectures in the early part of the semester (prior to series of fieldtrips).Student participation is highly valued and well integrated into the course.Dr. Draghi effectively uses class material effectively as a lens to analyze modern institutions.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: None.
might be helpful to be more structured

I enjoyed all of the classroom lectures, especially the discussion of topics such as: Perceval, the sacral kind (Domalde), Jung the collective unconscious, shamanism, myth, archetypes and their application to higher education. I would have liked to explore these topics in more depth throughout the course.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: No lab section.
field trips were great complements to the class
Very effective - see response to Q13.
N/A no lab or discussions.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course provided the type of "environmental philosophy" course that I was looking for.
it's a great foundation for me to have for the overall program
See response to Q13.

I understand natural science but i have always struggled with social science. I believe social science is complex and many answers to environmental problems are hidden in social science. It gave me a broader perspective on culture, art and its origin.

Though the course doesn't directly relate to my academic background, I felt that the class was very valuable to my FES experience. Dr. Draghi's class seeks to explore questions that directly relate to why scholars are drawn to study the environment.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I've heard great things about Paul, and this is the only course that he teaches. It looked very different from all the other courses at F&ES.
Interested in the religious and artistic aspects of this course
See response to Q13.
I wanted to know more and be a part of Yale. I wanted to take wide range of subjects in my first semester and then concentrate more in the following semesters.
I was looking for a course that look at the metaphysical aspects of our relation to the environment.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes, definitely.
Exceeded.
discussions about philosophies and art related to archetypes and the environment
Yes, very much so. See response to Q13.
Yes, it did. I have learnt to appreciate art and culture better than I was before I took the course.
Yes, the course met my expectations. The course has inspired me to delve into informal study of established scholars like Jung and Campbell as well as newcomers like David Abrams.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: try to participate in the class discussions and come to every class if you want to get the most out of the class.
Take it. It will expose you to many concepts and ideas and a different way of thinking that you won't get out of any other course at F&ES.
try to do as much readings as possible. time is likely to run out very fast.
Don't miss this opportunity!!!

I feel everybody should try taking this course. It is very interesting and you would be fascinated to learn so much. Sometimes you are almost buried in the facts that you fail to recognize the other aspects of nature. This is a good opportunity to learn about nature in a different genre of learning. I believe there are many treasures hidden around us and only if we look carefully enough with the right guide would you be able to discover it. This course is a good guide.
I would encourage them to be self-directed in terms of the reading and getting the most out of the course.
